job_title: Pre Service Specialist in Springfield, MO
pros: CoxHealth has great job options for those who want to work on campus or remotely.
cons: I haven't found many downsides to working for Cox. I've been with them for about 9 months and love working remotely.

job_title: Environmental Services Technician in Springfield, MO
pros: - Lots of exercise - Opportunity to switch departments at 6 months
cons: - Managers refuse to address training needs of staff leaving other departments frustrated with "You" even if you have no control. - Managers gossip and talk the rumor mill with hourly employees even when it's concerning illegal activities - Management will retaliate against you for going to HR to try and stop the drama happening in the department. - Director of ops refuses to address the problems on the shift due to a conflict of interest. ( long time friends with managers) - HR is no help as everytime they are contacted they just forward the message to the director of Ops. - Pay raises don't keep up with inflation. - constant threats to employment

pros: Coxhealth does care about its employees. However, management does not.
cons: It may be not obvious to untrained eye. But there’s racism and prejudice when you want to get a higher position.

review_title: Never had a Boss like that.
pros: Excellent coworkers, some of the sweetest patients, and hospital experience, no experience necessary
cons: The pay is not nearly enough for what you're doing. They expect you to be part CNA, transporter, housekeeper, and radiology assistant all in one barely-surviving-wage. They are absolutely not the company to be with while you're pregnant either. Don't call off if your head is in the toilet and you have uncontrollable vomiting either, all pregnancy related sickness doesn't matter, you're still coming in. They fired me for calling off too many days in my first trimester when I had hyperemesis. That's illegal.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist (ASCP) in Branson, MO
pros: Shift flexibility and hours were good. Most equipment is up to par and state if the art.
cons: Terrible management/ terrible supervisors. Like a messed up remake of Mean Girls only Regina George gets away with everything by complaining about how mean all her employees are towards her. Bullying is acceptable somehow and when brought to the attention of higher ups they sweep it under the rug.

review_title: Lack of respect by senior management
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Springfield, MO
pros: Work life balance is good, direct supervisors good, stress minimal outside clinic work.
cons: Lack of respect by senior management.

review_title: Great staff, always happy to assist in whatever training needs.
pros: Great hours and staff. Friendly people.
cons: Benefits could be a little bit better.

pros: Great management. Very supportive and helpful.
cons: They definitely put a lot of emphasis on productivity

pros: Competitive salary, good retirement, good hours, decent insurance
cons: Asked for additional training & was ignored on multiple occasions. Not good team work. Management does not listen to and/or help employees unless there is an issue with the employee and then they attack you in front of everyone on chat group. The company takes your ETO if you haven't worked there greater than 3 years and don't tell you they are because policy says, " if terminated" and even though you were not fired they consider it "voluntary termination." Huge turnover at CoxHealth at Home they have fired eight people in just a few years. Those training you don't care if you succeed or fail and will blast your failures on group chats. The company closed three of their outlying offices with a four week notice and told the effected employees the same day they announced to the entire company. The employees who lost their jobs had zero compensation. Not a good place to work at all.

job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Springfield, MO
pros: Pay is alright, plenty of OT, Benefits
cons: Required OT, back breaking work, bad management depending on the department you work in.

review_title: Overall Company Seems to Care about Employees

pros: They seem to care about employees, offering occasional free meals or coffee on key dates. You can win bonus points to exchange for gift cards.
cons: Insurance is awful- like we work where we get healthcare. Do better. High premiums and OOP costs. My direct management was nitpicky, only loved to tell everyone how much they sucked and never took time to look at our strengths. She also seemed to take her grief out of coworkers instead of getting a therapist.

review_title: Had to work night shift for better pay

review_title: I wish I could give five stars
pros: There's no doubt everyone working for CoxHealth cares about their community and the success of the hospital. Acts of kindness and generosity among staff toward each other and patients are a daily, regular occurrence here. You will be treated with tremendous kindness and respect. No doubt. I never felt obligated to go above and beyond for the organization, but I happily do so when I have the opportunity to help. I love what I do and the people I work with, but I just can't afford to work here.
cons: For a salaried employee, benefits are dismal. The ETO is shameful, bordering on unethical. If you can make it to five years you'll finally, maybe, be able to take time off for leisure rather than desperately hoarding your hours for when you or your kids get sick, or say, Christmas and other holidays. And their "paid maternity leave" is two weeks that would normally be covered by your impossible-to-access sick bank anyway. It's practically nothing. Also, the pay is rough and HC premiums are sky high.

pros: Remote work after training period.
cons: They will target you and criticize everything to the point you are desperate to leave

job_title: Patient Registration Specialist in Springfield, MO
pros: Working with great people. Can be flexible with schedule. Paid time off. Benefits.
cons: Never adequately staffed due to budget. When medical staff and patient volume increased the registration dept. was still as small as ever. High turn over rate due to staffing issues and new hires feeling overwhelmed and unprepared. Can many times end up doing the work of two people. Not all leadership pitches in to help.

pros: I enjoyed working as a pharmacy technician. I felt as if I was making a difference in patient lives.
cons: Technicians and pharmacists fraternized outside of employment which bred fraternization. If you weren’t part of the in crowd than you got the hours people didn’t want, overlooked for PTO requests, positions that no one else wanted. Lots of gossip and backstabbing. Some worked very hard while some favorite technicians were hardly working. Benefits are horrible for a hospital. Nurses treat you as if you’re not important to the company and felt they could talk to you any way. Double billed patients by resending the same medication because staff on the floors were not responsible to placing medication where it should be. Pay was NOT a living wage. The pay has increased as of this year.

pros:
It is family and once you are there it is hard to leave. The only way to get fired is to be stupid, show a lack of integrity or ethics or be rude. If you have problems in your life outside of work they will help and adjust to assist. 

I have seen the management work with employees and leaders with alcoholism. Instead of firing them, potential leading those people to a worse situation, the hospital gave them opportunities to fight their ailment and still work in an environment or on tasks that wouldn't hurt the hospital, patients or co-workers. 

These people are sober now and still working in the hospital.

Also the non-smoking campus is a plus!!!
They do a nicotine test when you are hired, so it helps to motivate some to quit the habit.
cons:
Raises in service department jobs need to be discussed an adjusted. The doctors and medical jobs are on a pedestal, and the jobs that keep the campus clean, people feed and working are treated as cheap labor. 
At times the hospital will use private contractors for certain jobs and pay them exorbitant amounts; but then turn around and pay scratch to the employees they already have for those jobs.

pros: Other employees have been great to work with-My immediate supervisory is great.
cons: minimal pay advancement for tenure

review_title: Why I Have Worked For CoxHealth for 28 Years
pros: To try to be concise, the caring attitude of our staff for our patients is the number one reason.  We all work as a team, trying to give the best care possible, efficiently, while not forgetting the "human touch" along the way.  Administration is very transparent and supportive of staff, which we all greatly appreciate.  I think it is fair to say that almost all the employees of CoxHealth consider themselves to be part of a very large family made up of very nice caring people.  It wasn't a goal of mine, but my work as a hospital pharmacist has taken me to all of our campuses over the years, mostly to help out when there were needs on the other campuses.  Each facility I have been at, and my work with Regional Services over the years, reinforces the truth to the "big family" statement I made earlier.  Someday I will retire, and I suspect I will do as many of my friends here have done - become a volunteer for CoxHealth in some capacity to continue helping others.
cons: I really don't have any.  You always want your deductible to be less, or this and that, be seriously there is a reason those are set the way they are.  CoxHealth is a great place to work.  I recommend it!

pros: Quality Care and Advanced Technology

pros: As my degree of study is in psychology this has been a great starting job overall.  I have learn much from the experience of the job an the coworkers.  The staff will work to have your back and keep each other safe. They are caring an therapudic to the patients and to each other. Overall the job can be rewarding.
cons: Much like many other jobs mangagement can hold the staff back in their ability to provide a safe and therapudic enviroment for all both staff and patients. Though they may try to be involved they tend to be more of a hinderence at times than a help in situations that are critical.

review_title: Very low pay, especially considering workload.
pros: [Radiology] Good opportunity to experience large workloads of general radiography, fluoroscopy, surgery, and emergency examinations.
cons: Ridiculously low pay. Nobody who respects their profession should be willing to work for what this hospital system pays for skilled technologists and (from what I hear) nurses. The pay is lower than any place I've ever even heard of, and the entire (brief) time I was there, I was searching for alternative employment. Meanwhile the organization acquires other hospital facilities and spends millions expanding. There's no convincing me that they can't afford to respectfully employ their talented staff.

pros: Helping the patients is the only thing I enjoyed about that place.
cons:
Being unappreciated no matter how long you work there. I had to carry the weight of incompetent leaders, was forced to work long hours with barely a break due to lack of staffing, had to deal with two faced gossiping leaders who stir the pot, management lie and promise things they do not follow through with, leaders sacrifice the well being of their employees under the guise of "doing what's best for the patients" and being paid crap to deal with all of that. 
I would never, EVER recommend ANYONE to work for the Coxhealth Admissions department. I had to start taking depression medication after working there, and their health insurance they offer is the worst in town. 
Shame on Cox for their poor management and lack of concern for their terrible work environment in the Admissions department.

pros:
The senior leadership here at Cox really does care about what happens within the organization. From taking the time to talk directly with patients and families to gather input or hear concerns or allowing an employee to voice an opinion or idea in a forum and really taking the time to look into or address it, these actions are so valuable. 
I've worked in 3 different departments in the organization and have always been very happy. There is always room to advance in the organization, by taking advantage of opportunities within the department and outside as well.
I feel Cox does a great job trying to support its employees and as well as trying to do what is truly best for our patients.
cons: Sometimes the lunch options on campus can be little lacking.

pros: Lots of overtime opportunities. You could pretty much live in the lab and get paid for it if you wanted.
cons: Extremely understaffed (and therefore overworked) on two out of three shifts and ridiculously underpaid. Lab higher-ups would rather pay existing employees overtime than go to HR for a market-based raise to help attract prospective employees, which is just pure stupidity.   There are never enough lab employees to fully staff the lab overnight and it is only getting worse. Employees are leaving left and right, and prospective hires repeatedly turn down job offers because the pay is so low. It is insulting.

pros: The pay is fair for the number of months/hours worked. Most instructors are on 9 month contracts. Administration of the college is accessible and open to input from instructors. Teaching is a wonderful experience.
cons: The college is disorganized. A school that has been operating for so long should have everything smoothed out. Every semester feels like a chaotic mess with last minute changes to faculty load and assigned courses. The instructors and students suffer from this habitual lack of planning. College administration changes frequently, creating an unstable environment of paranoid people.

review_title: I enjoy my job at CoxHealth.
pros:
Opportunity for advancement
They will pay some or most of your education. 
Employee discounts at Cox and some surrounding businesses
They allow payroll deduct for employee health, the employee store, gift shop, Atrium, and cafeteria. 
They care for our community. 
All kinds of resources
cons: Biggest con:  When I interviewed, I was misled regarding ETO. I was led to believe that we had paid holidays and that sick time was separate from ETO. In reality, once you think you've saved up enough time for a couple days off, a holiday will come around, and your time is gone or it dwindles quickly. This would have been a deal breaker, had I known before accepting my position.

review_title: The current administration has inherited a bad culture and is making efforts to communicate better.
pros: It is a very community oriented organization.
cons: Not a place for anyone looking to grow into a career. They have a preference for hiring outside rather than promoting from within.

pros: The coaches and coordinators are all fun loving health nuts. The job itself is not hard and the hours are flexible leaving you free to plan your own schedule.
cons: The office is primarily female and sometimes there tends to be more drama than there should be in a work place due to a few bad apples. The work is tedious and sometimes can be very slow and then shift to extrmemely busy overnight.

review_title: This is a very hierarchail organization that should spend more time worring about patient care.
pros:
They encourage friendships with co-workers and the lower-level management really cares about the employees. 
They offer a wide variety of benefits to employees.
cons:
There are too many layers of management to go through to get anything done.  With such a big organization, one can feel lost in the shuffle.  
They are down-sizing and many employees are getting their jobs eliminated with little or no notice at all.

pros: It's a fast pace job and no day is ever the same. I can work independently or as a group. I also work with a good group of coworkers. There's ample opportunity to continually improve my telecommunication as well as customer service skills.
cons: Management could use some improvement. As the new systems come into the department, there was inadequate training. The hospital needs to update their ventilation system, as I work in the basement and still inhale the exhaust fumes from the helicopter.

pros: They offer benefits, health is better than none at all , vision is excellent , gym membership is over priced dental is avail
cons: Too many administrators running amuck making life hell , over worked,  under paid , work load is overwhelming for just one medical assistant in some areas while others spend the day with very little work load and half days ,environment is hostile and constant fear for ones job , team work is non existent set up to fail if not excepted by the politics.

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Springfield, MO
pros: The employees are a great bunch of people truly dedicated to taking care of people. Payroll withdrawal for medical bills. Tuition reimbursement.
cons: Management is very sketchy. Some departments are great, some make your worst nightmares seem pleasant(surgery dept). Surgery department management create a negative/bullying environment and are manly concerned with how many surgeries can be jammed into a day.Lunch/bathroom breaks are considered a luxury. Pay is significantly lower than  the national average. Health insurance for employees and family is expensive.

pros: You get to actually help people who are depressed and teach them coping skills.  At the end of the day you feel like you did some good in the world. Good insurance and benefits,decent eto, 75 percent good coworkers, steve edwards the ceo actually cares, and good supervisors. You get to make a difference in a patient's life sometimes. Out of all the floors f200 adult pysch ll is the best as well as senior adult psych. F300 adult psych l and child adolescent are not as good.
cons: It seems hard for them to fire people that are lazy and don't do their jobs. You might be the hard worker and have a coworker on patient care with you that sits  in the nursing station all night.Also I have gone to staff assists to help with aggressive patients and been sent back to my floor due to me being a woman. Men seem to be valued more and not by management but by nurses. Even if you are a good deescalator and a woman, your male coworker will be valued more. When performing safety checks every 15 minutes you are not allowed to do anything else so it can get boring. Usually they will have you switch off every 2 or 4 hours. You could get hurt with an out of control patient however they train you well and your coworkers have your back. You may have to float to another psych floor however that is easy and usually happens 2 times every 6 months. Some people micro manage even when not in charge. Some gossip as well. You hear some heart breaking patient stories. They prefer a bachelors degree but hire some non educated people which makes you feel like you went to school for no reason except an extra 50 cents and hour.

pros: Great education department, great people to work with,plenty of overtime available, good benifits package including pension, employee recognition programs, tuition reimbursement
cons: Management lack of ability to see past the numbers of nurse to pt ratio, low pay scale, mandatory overtime,removal of bonus money for overtime

review_title: Major dis function between system leadership and site hospitals.
pros: Branson is a wonderful place to work.  Everyone is treated like family.   Branson administration is actively involved with all departments.  Great collaboration between all departments.
cons: System directors are focused on Springfield hospitals and expect all site hospitals to function the same way.  There are favorites within the organization. Health insurance is the worst.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse/IV in Springfield, MO
pros: The people and nurses are top notch.
cons: Pay is below industry standard

pros: Staff works well together, great team work. Management tries to accommodate work scheduling and improving communication.
cons:
Pay is substandard for nursing. The pay ceiling is low and "merit increases" apparently are just a fiction if you are bumping up against the pay ceiling. A merit increase of "2.5%" can translate to a mere 33 cents an hour. That is about as good as I got working in high school at McDonald's...very insulting after many years of nursing experience and care. Explains turnover rate.
2) Benefits. Not inexpensive. Cafeteria is expensive for meals...even with an employee discount, it is comparable to eating takeout. When you pay almost 5 dollars for a small cup of soup and a small salad...that's pretty expensive, even with a "discount". 
3) Time off/low census: Push is for low census on numbers...you better be prepared to eat your paycheck or use up vacation hours at the convenience of the hospital. As a result, what they say you are working and getting paid for is a false narrative. You might be hired to work 80 hours a pay period, but if you are low censused (meaning you don't work because the hospital doesn't have enough patients), you either use your vacation time (earned) to fill the gap or you don't get paid. Unlike the salary scale, there is no cap to low census hours either. So you are essentially laid off without being laid off. Works great for the hospital, not so great when you have bills to pay. 
4) Holidays: you either get time and a half for the 6 major holidays or you take the day off...that would be without pay or use your vacation pay. in other words, there are NO Paid Holidays.
Earned Time Off: pretty limited the first few years...you get less than 3 weeks a year as an RN..well below the national average. 
In summary: the hospital's pay and benefits are well below the national average.

job_title: Emergency Department RN in Springfield, MO
pros: Great facility to get top notch training. This is a Level 1 Trauma center and I honestly believe you’ll get the best training available. The top leadership in the ER are strong advocates of their nurses.
cons: Pay is significantly less than the national average for RN's. This creates extremely high turnover. As soon as people get trained they leave the area for higher paying jobs. Benefits are more costly than most other employers this size.

pros: The individuals I worked with were friendly and enjoyable to be around.  The benefits are good and there is a good work-life balance.  Employees are encouraged to submit new ideas and are recognized for their input.
cons: As with any big organization, the encouragement to submit new ideas exists but addressing and change come very slow.

review_title: Great company, decent benefits, proud to call Cox Health my employer
pros: There are numerous opportunities for advancement if you are willing to stick with the company. Cox tends to promote from within for those individuals who are willing to devote many years to the organization.
cons: Unless you are a well-paid clinician or a in a senior management position, the compensation is just about average for the regional health care market.

Suggestions for improvement fell on deaf ears.  Not empowered to make changes to improve hospital.  Little  appreciation and recognition  given to employees.

pros: The pros are that they will work with you in case of a family emergency.  They also have a better record that other hospitals in the area
cons: CoxHealth still holds to the old stigmas and will allow the find a way to fire employees if they develop a mental illness or if they discover that you have one to begin with

review_title: Care more about image than employees

cons:

pros: Nice people - staff seem to care about what they do. New addition to hospital is nice and clean. Good foundation of shared governance for nursing.
cons: Very average. Hospital isn't as clean as it should be. Top executives are rigid and difficult to talk to. Find the environment stifling and difficult to advance. Nursing leadership is dysfunctional - in that not many get along with each other and don't follow the same rules. Some are held accountable and many are not.

review_title: Would recommend anyone nurse to apply here
pros: Wonderful leadership. Everyone takes pride in working for Cox. Voted 417’s best place to work in Springfield. Pay is comparable to competitors in the area, although it is below the national standard for RN’s. There is a career ladder for nurses to earn extra money each year and they offer tuition reimbursement.
cons: I would love to see Cox reach magnet status, which I know they have been working towards and will achieve eventually.

pros: The patients, and co-workers, the cafeteria was adequate.
cons: Poor communication, pay, benefits and benefit package. Again communication wad terrible and if you are targeted, it is a which hunt to make sure you are guilty, I had no advocate or counsel present, but I dif not believe it would be necessary.

pros: Great team work and sense of community in the department where I work. Feel supported by my co-workers.
cons: Health insurance is terrible & pay is inadequate for our area. Leadership does not enforce accountability or responsibility, rather they "blanket" concerns or issues of concern instead of holding individuals accountable.

pros: Management is open to new ideas from their employees and treat you like family. The work environment is really light and upbeat. Management and coworkers are always encouraging and there is room for promotions and improvement in this position. They also provide tuition discount and reimbursement for Cox College students which is fantastic. Highly recommend working for this company in this position!
cons: I have nothing here to complain about!

review_title: I loved my time at Cox
job_title: Infant Hearing Screening Technician in Springfield, MO
pros: CoxHealth is an excellent place to work. Coworkers are very kind and helpful and you get semi frequent meetings with bosses (4-5 times a year) to discuss your work and any concerns/suggestions you have.
cons: Near constant education on hospital policies. You had classes on the computer that you had to do every year, but they’re so spaced out that you almost always have something due.

review_title: Probably the worst employer that I've ever had!
pros: If you are applying to cox there are some good aspects. To start off they are a growing company, with this new tower that they are building there will be opportunities to move around in the operation. They do offer full-time employees insurance, retirement, and time off. The cafeteria is tolerable and even sometimes good! They offer somewhat flexible hours as well.
cons:
I've been for the company long enough to understand that I'm nothing more than a number. I gave up my identity the day I started working there. 

To Start off, they have changed so many policies since I've started at Cox that are meant to weed out the people who have been there the longest, and therefore make the most money, in attempts to save money.

In addition to these new policies they cut staff to absolutely bare minimum, sometimes less, to save money. Patient care is only third to making money and paying administrations salaries. 

 While you may be scheduled for 36 hours, you might only end up with 32 or less by the end of the week depending on weather they force you to stay home. If you are forced to stay home, you have to use the time that you save up for vacation or sick leave to make up your wages. Heaven forbid you need to use your sick bank time either. You're not able to use that time unless you fill out FMLA (even if it is only 1 day), and then they decide on your eligibility, so you might not even be able to use the time you have saved for 3 years. 

The wages that they offer are to say the least embarrassing. As a full time employee who has direct patient care, I made far less that $25,000 last year. Most of this is due to the absences that they mandatorily put their staff on. Meanwhile they raise the cost of benefits, and lower the coverage. It is almost literally impossible to afford to work here if you are not in administration. 

This treatment is across the board for Nursing Assistants, Nurses, Respiratory therapist, or anyone else doing direct patient care. Overall I'll say when someone ask me where I work, I have to say, I'm embarrassed to say Cox Health.

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Springfield, MO
pros: It's better than having no job at all, I suppose.  There are some things company wide that are nice, such as gym memberships, etc.
cons: Pay is nearly 2.00 less than hospitals a mile down the street!!!  clickish atmosphere, difficult to work through office politics, management won't speak about issues until serious problems arise

pros: Helping people and benefits like Earned Time Off.
cons:
Techs get fired from a speck of dust on an instrument, but surgeons can be billigerent and abuse their support staff every day without consequence. 

Management demands accountability for minor errors while Doctors can come down and verbally abuse and harass SPD staff and surg techs whenever they feel like it with immunity. 

An SPD staff member approached OR management about a problem and was told to, "back off". 

Another time, clinical abuse was reported to HR regarding a surgeon verbally harassing mutiple staff. Weeks later, and there was still no formal apology from the doctor. 

With toothless management, SPD atmosphere became extremely toxic and techs became cynical about their work. 

I left healthcare. 

The word of middle management has no power over the word of a surgeon who can sue the **** out of the hospital if something happens that they don't like. 

Cox Hospital can never be "Be the best for those who need us" if doctors aren't held accountable for their behavior and actions. 

Accountability can't happen without recording equipment in both SPD and the OR to capture this abusive behavior in the act and give staff and the hospital a legal leg to stand on. 

But hospitals like Cox will never provide real transparency for patients or justice for abused support staff because they'll never take the legal risk of having cameras in the OR to help keep surgeons accountable. 

Until further notice: take your lashes and shut up or leave. They don't care about replaceable support staff. They only care about protecting their company from real threats like sue-happy doctors or patients who could smear the company in the news. 

Nobody cares about the word of a support tech.

pros: Love the people you spend each day around. Developed a sense of community. The nursing staff work hard and give great care to the patients.
cons: Leadership are into SP=self-preservation. No longer into doing what is right. More concerned about how it looks- especially the CNO.

review_title: Great Company to work for. I absolutely love my job.
pros: Great pay and flexible schedule. Cox is very willing to pay for education. I feel very proud to say I work for Cox Health.
cons: I do not have anything to complain about. Cox is a great organization to work for and I feel proud to work for them

pros: While I have met some lovely people while working at Cox South, I would not recommend you work there if you are looking to make a living wage.

review_title: Overall great experience with high quality staff.

cons: Under midwest average in pay but competitive with local competition. Company wide computer system is not very user friendly and is constantly updating with changes.

pros: The company has comparable insurance and good retirement plans. Depending on the department you work in, you work with great people and become like a family. Great for experience and seeing if you want to continue in the healthcare field.
cons: Seems to be a constant shortage of staff. Staff is usually always overwhelmed and overworked.

pros: I truly believe that this company has the best interest of it's employees at heart. I have specifically worked in the MICU for two and a half years and especially believe that the management over that unit has my back as an employee.
cons: No job is perfect, but I don't have a specific complaint.

pros: I guess it just depends on the departments you work in.  I transferred to different areas over the years.  Some were great, others not so much.
cons: Keep records of everything.  Reviews, notes, etc.  Supervisors won't hesitate to throw you under the bus to protect themselves.

pros: Friendly staff, experienced management, long term employees, close contact with physicians and the school/ students, efforts for improvements, close working environments

pros: Flexible hours, friendly atmosphere, many opportunities to explore careers within.
cons: Careers outside tourism are very hard to find in Branson. Because CoxHealth is one of the best non-tourism based employers available in the area, there are a lot of applicants, and as such it is difficult to land a full-time position quickly.

pros: Feels like home and is small enough that you can easily know a lot of people here.
cons: People in leadership are hired based on their degrees not on their ability, skills, morals or ethics. WWTK surveys are conducted yearly but the staff rarely sees any change as a result.

pros: Benefits are great! The healthcare professionals are the best in the Ozark's. The culture is respected in the community as welcoming and personal.
cons: Without Medicaid expansion in Missouri it causes Cox and other hospitals in MO the pressures of not having the ability to compete in salaries with non clinical employees.

pros: The coworkers and pharmacists were great to work with.
